November 3, 1985: Fiction
TEXAS, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $21.95.) Four hundred fifty
years of history in fictional form.
LAKE WOBEGON DAYS, by Garrison Keillor. (Viking, $17.95.) Recollections of a
small American town.
SECRETS, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $17.95.) Behind the scenes during the
production of a blockbuster television series.
CONTACT, by Carl Sagan. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) The commotion that
follows the reception of a signal from intelligent life beyond Earth.
GALAPAGOS, by Kurt Vonnegut. (Delacorte/ Seymour Lawrence, $16.95.)
Mankind's sole survivors, passengers on a Pacific cruise, conclude Darwin's
theory of evolution is correct.
THE SECRETS OF HARRY BRIGHT, by Joseph Wambaugh. (Morrow, $17.95.) A
detective searches for the meaning of his own son's death while investigating a
killing in the California desert.
LUCKY, by Jackie Collins. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) The heiress of a crime
lord takes on the heiress of a shipping tycoon.
THE ACCIDENTAL TOURIST, by Anne Tyler. (Knopf, $16.95.) Family and female
friends impose order of a kind on the errant life of a male travel writer.
SKELETON CREW, by Stephen King. (Putnam, $18.95.) Twenty-two tales of
horror set in contemporary America.
THE TWO MRS. GRENVILLES, by Dominick Dunne. (Crown, $14.95.) Romance,
scandal and murder in New York's high society.
DEPTHS OF GLORY, by Irving Stone. (Doubleday, $19.95.) A biographical novel
of the painter Camille Pissarro.
THE IMMIGRANT'S DAUGHTER, by Howard Fast. (Houghton Mifflin, $17.95.)
The concluding volume of the Lavelle saga tells of a woman involved in today's
politics.
LONESOME DOVE, by Larry McMurtry. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) The Old
West seen larger than life.
A MAGGOT, by John Fowles. (Little, Brown, $19.95.) Five travelers in 18th-
century England have mysterious, wonderful and eerie adventures.
THE RED FOX, by Anthony Hyde. (Knopf, $17.95.) A spy thriller in which a
journalist journeys to the Soviet Union, seeking the father of the woman he loves.
November 3, 1985
Non-Fiction
ELVIS AND ME, by Priscilla Beaulieu Presley with Sandra Harmon. (Putnam,
$16.95.) The rock legend as friend, mentor, lover, husband, father.
DANCING IN THE LIGHT, by Shirley MacLaine. (Bantam, $17.95.) The
entertainer wins an Oscar, survives a stormy romance and has new visions.
YEAGER: An Autobiography, by Chuck Yeager and Leo Janos. (Bantam, $17.95.)
The story of the first man to fly faster than sound.
IACOCCA: An Autobiography, by Lee Iacocca with William Novak. (Bantam,
$19.95.) The rise of an immigrants' son to top jobs at Ford and Chrysler.
I NEVER PLAYED THE GAME, by Howard Cosell with Peter Bonventre. (Morrow,
$18.95.) A dour view of the sports world by the broadcaster.
HOUSE, by Tracy Kidder. (Houghton Mifflin, $17.95.) An account of the
construction of a Greek Revival house in Massachusetts.
ON THE ROAD WITH CHARLES KURALT, by Charles Kuralt. (Putnam, $16.95.)
The television reporter tells of Americans he's encountered.
GODDESS, by Anthony Summers. (Macmillan, $18.95.) The ''secret lives'' of
Marilyn Monroe.
LIVING WITH THE KENNEDYS, by Marcia Chellis. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.)
The experiences of Joan Kennedy.
A PASSION FOR EXCELLENCE, by Tom Peters and Nancy Austin. (Random
House, $19.95.) Ways to achieve distinction in management.
SMART WOMEN, FOOLISH CHOICES, by Connell Cowan and Melvyn Kinder.
(Clarkson N. Potter, $13.95.) Women's efforts to find acceptable men.
COMMON GROUND, by J. Anthony Lukas. (Knopf, $19.95.) How school
desegregation affected three Boston families from 1968 to 1978.
RE-INVENTING THE CORPORATION, by John Naisbitt and Patricia Aburdene.
(Warner, $17.50.) Opportunities in ''the new information society.''
LAST WISH, by Betty Rollin. (Linden/Simon & Schuster, $14.95.) The ordeal of a
woman whose mother, dying of cancer, wishes to commit suicide.
FERRARO: My Story, by Geraldine A. Ferraro with Linda Bird Francke. (Bantam,
$17.95.) The rise of an immigrants' daughter to become the first female Vice-
Presidential nominee of a major party.
DELOREAN, by John Z. Delorean with Ted Schwarz. (Zondervan, $17.95.) The
